text:
In a bit of situation with my workload/taking on more client work. Short version is that I'm working at an agency while writing/managing one client's content (around 4x articles a month) - totally manageable. But the issue is I have few more referral/leads (1-2 for now) coming in for more potential content writing work (mostly clients) - I'm guessing the next obvious step is to outsource/get another writer for the new client work and I'm kind stuck there.

I'm thinking of getting another writer (semi-new experience who wouldn't charge _too_ much) writing the content for the new client under my wing (with me giving them directions/outline/editing and stamp of approval before submitting to client). For this, I think it makes sense to ask for a higher-than-normal pricing for the client, right and to split the pay with my writer? (60/40? Something like that?) I think I would rather do something like that than just say I'm unavailable and refer the client to someone else. Anyone been there done that? Any tips/insights welcome!

(PS - bonus question, assuming I find a writer for me to manage for the client. Do I let the client know someone else is writing the content with me editing and giving the stamp of approval? Or is it just kind of like a white-label and I claim it because I'll be interacting with the client and submitting the work? Or am I just really overthinking this :sweat_smile:)

Just trying to figure out how to approach this as I don't want to take on all the work for myself and get overwhelmed. Any direction/insights welcome :smile:

text:
My two cents:
• Charging the client more for the work just because you don’t have the bandwidth to do it yourself is not a good move. The deliverable should cost what the deliverable costs.
• Whatever writer you bring on board (I’m assuming a freelancer) will have their own rate and estimates for this work. You should pay them their rate for the deliverable, not split the income from the client.
• Whether or not the writer should work directly with the client is dependent on the deliverable - for something simple, then it makes sense for there to be no client interaction, but it can often be useful to allow the writer to interface directly with the client. Don’t sacrifice the quality of the work just because you’re getting freelance help. And you can be transparent about it.

text: Makes a lot of sense, appreciate it! Yeah I was thinking of being transparent about it, think the client would be fine with it too.  My thought process for the rates was to charge 20%-40% up what I usually charge (as I like to increase rates with each new client/project) and to split the cost based on that (of course, if everyone is satisfied with the rates in that hypothetical). Of course, I will check the client/freelancer's expectations first with their rates and go from there (not the other way around), but I guess I was thinking backward with the ideal situation with the pricing :smile: Wasn't sure how to approach this as I don't want to let the lead guy as I think it's a good opportunity and don't want to take the work on myself and burn down down the road

text:
:wave:
Another 5 kopeeks:
• Agree on the first item, the pricing for the client has to be transparent. On the other hand, the complexity of the subject, availability of resources from client, and urgency will affect the price anyway. So if it is a project with a short deadline and you need extra set of hands, the client will pay for urgency and you will be able to allocate part of that price for your partner.
• Semi-agree on second item. For example, I have my own rate, but if the client comes in from your personal brand and not mine, that means you did a job to get them, and I would be willing to go a bit lower on my price to work with you and your network. Also, <@U01KVQWUZQ8> mentions doing the outline and editing (which otherwise I’d have to maintain myself), so that takes a bit of work off my (the vendor’s) plate. If they accept the conditions beforehand, of course.
• If you find a person who is your trusted helper, not just a wordsmith mercenary, it is probably okay to let them connect to a client as your associate. And I believe it will make your collaboration fun and enjoyable, instead of purely commercial, so I hope you will find a person like that!

text:
Hi <@U01KVQWUZQ8>
You’re not overthinking this! it’s a great idea to get another ‘semi-new’ writer and groom them. Esp. when you need more hands on deck. At our agency, we work with young writers all the time — we ensure they learn on the job, sit in on client meetings, and also get what they’re due on their experience and quality.

We built a network of writers, and now when we get clients for content work, we get someone from the pool of writers to execute the writing. We keep QC and coordination with us.

Of course, we vet the writers we work with. We designed our own ‘Values Form’ (it goes beyond grammar and mechanics of the language TBH).
May be this (or similar) is something you want to consider implementing when you pick more writers? <http://bit.ly/ValuesForm>

Best of luck! :raised_hands::skin-tone-4:
